main event: A cigar-shaped object hovered over Charlestown, West Virginia for approximately 15 minutes, emitting a bright light and appearing to be about 100 feet long. It disappeared suddenly in an upward direction.
interesting points: An amateur astronomer photographed a round luminous object near the edge of the moon from Broadway, Virginia on March 4.

A retired city police officer well known in the community reported seeing a bright, disc-like object move across the sky around 8:50 PM on April 7, 1955. The sighting was confirmed by other independent witnesses in the area.

On March 3, 1955, a round, very tight object the size of a balloon was observed for about 3-5 seconds in Charleston, West Virginia. The sighting had the characteristics of a balloon, and a check with the local weather station indicated weather conditions were conducive to balloon sightings.

The Project Blue Book report card stated that due to the brevity of the sighting and the impossibility of determining the course or duration of the lighting observation, no estimation was made of velocity, height, distance, or size.
The Project Blue Book report card noted that the sighted object had all the characteristics of a balloon, and possibly a UR-16 minutes prior to the sighting.
sighted object: A cigar-shaped object, a round luminous object, and a round, very tight object the size of a balloon
location: Charlestown, West Virginia; Broadway, Virginia; Charleston, West Virginia
witnesses: Civilian, amateur astronomer, retired city police officer
photographs: Yes, the report includes photographs of a round luminous object near the edge of the moon
